item.title: Today in history, January 15: Australia's London Bridge fell down
item.description: Seconds after her cousin reassured her crossing it was safe, the famous Great Ocean Road formation started collapsing beneath Kelli Bryers's feet, setting off a terrifying ordeal.

item.title: Tens of thousands of livestock confirmed dead as Victorians return to bushfire-ravaged communities
item.description: Around 260 homes have been confirmed destroyed and 20,000 head of livestock killed by bushfires across Victoria, with authorities warning the total is likely to rise.

item.title: Sussan Ley signals Liberals won’t back 'unsalvageable' hate crime and gun control reforms
item.description: Liberals are backing away from a push to tackle antisemitism with stronger racial hatred laws, with some senior figures in the party also voicing freedom of speech concerns.

item.title: Who to see at Tamworth Country Music Festival 2026 — top artists and event details
item.description: Discover the must-see artists at the 2026 Tamworth Country Music Festival — from breakout stars like Lane Pittman to legends such as Felicity Urquhart. Your ultimate guide to shows, dates, and insider tips.

item.title: From inside Iran, a young protester says the people 'are waiting for America to intervene'
item.description: A defiant voice bravely breaks through Iran's internet blackout to detail the horrors she has witnessed and to tell the president of the United States "the people are waiting for America to intervene".

item.title: Rental market growth stalls in some capital cities as household budgets stretched to limit
item.description: Australia's rental market is "starting to rebalance" with prices flat in some capital cities but affordability remains a concern, according to Domain, which says an annual salary of $100,000 is needed to live comfortably.

item.title: Writers' Week cancellation highlights SA premier's uneasy relationship with the arts
item.description: After backing the Adelaide Festival's decision to drop a Palestinian Australian author from Writers' Week, Peter Malinauskas is now trying to distance himself from a crisis that threatens to do untold damage to South Australia's festival reputation.

item.title: Jafar Panahi is ready to go to prison for the film the Iranian government doesn't want you to see
item.description: Would you face prison for what you believe in? Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi already has and, following the release of his latest film, he may again.

item.title: Reopening Gulgong Medical Centre a 'lifeline' for the community
item.description: Gulgong went 18 months without a GP clinic. It has now reopened, giving residents a reprieve from travelling hundreds of kilometres to see a doctor.

item.title: Trauma medics warn over-60s against climbing ladders as 6,000 people hospitalised in a year
item.description: Thousands of people present to Australian hospitals each year for ladder and roof falls, with doctors urging caution — particularly for ageing Australians.

item.title: Trump to write next chapter of US relations with Iran after decades of tensions
item.description: From a CIA-led coup to a hostage crisis and air strikes, here are some of the defining moments in seven decades of relations between the United States and Iran.

item.title: Bark microbes removing greenhouse gases
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Tree bark microbes play a role in eliminating greenhouse gases, study finds
item.description: Tiny, gas-eating microbes hidden in the bark of trees offer scientists a crucial clue in the fight against global warming.

item.title: Victorian families warn of risks after hiring au pairs through social media
item.description: Families who turned to social media to find an au pair say the lack of safeguards left them vulnerable to serious problems.

item.title: NT set to fall short of Indigenous law and justice target despite early success
item.description: Despite the NT government signing on to establish 20 Aboriginal Law and Justice Groups by 2027, just five are up and running with less than 12 months to go.

item.title: US to suspend immigrant visa processing for 75 countries, including Fiji
item.description: The US State Department will suspend processing of immigrant visas for people from 75 countries, including Fiji, Cambodia, Thailand, Somalia and Brazil, from January 21.

item.title: As Adelaide Writers' Week is cancelled, what is the future of writers' festivals in Australia?
item.description: The shock cancellation of Adelaide Writers' Week has left many concerned about the future of writers' festivals in an increasingly polarised political world.

item.title: Regulator investigates alleged breach of Alcoa's mining exemption conditions
item.description: WA's environmental regulator is investigating an alleged breach of Alcoa's state-imposed mining conditions which, if proven, would make it illegal for the company to continue some of its mining operations.

item.title: Australia's vet access deserts where an hour's drive is the difference in life and death
item.description: More than 250,000 people do not have ready access to a vet in Australia, and according to the industry, it is not completely down to a shortage. It is also a distribution issue, which is putting biosecurity at risk.

item.title: Brisbane Heat beat Hobart Hurricanes in stunning BBL finish
item.description: A spectacular bowling effort in the final overs and a key contribution from Marnus Labuschagne help the Brisbane Heat to an upset win over the Hobart Hurricanes to keep their BBL finals hopes alive.

item.title: Drought-hit grain growers make every drop of rain count
item.description: New techniques and technology are allowing southern NSW grain growers to produce a harvest, despite significantly below-average rainfall.

item.title: Coalition asks Albanese for the grace he was not afforded in the wake of Bondi attack
item.description: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

item.title: Why Alice Springs has become one of Australia's most prolific literary towns
item.description: With many local authors, Alice Springs is no longer just a setting for stories by writers from elsewhere. It is becoming one of Australia's most distinctive literary centres with homegrown talent inspired by the Red Centre's landscape.

item.title: Calls for greater transparency as WA government's annual reports into youth suicide delayed
item.description: Fearing more lives will be lost, Kimberley Aboriginal leaders call on the WA government to release updates on parliamentary and coronial recommendations into youth suicide.

item.title: Moment SpaceX spacecraft with sick astronaut undocks from ISS
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: SpaceX capsule begins return to Earth from International Space Station with sick astronaut on board
item.description: The Crew Dragon capsule has undocked from the International Space Station carrying four astronauts, one of whom has a "serious medical condition", and is on its way back to Earth.

item.title: Two French men to plead guilty over alleged $10m luxury theft in Canberra
item.description: Lawyers say the value of the allegedly stolen luxury goods, including a $5 million Richard Mille watch, is disputed as the case returns to court.

item.title: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to Randa Abdel-Fattah over Adelaide Writers' Week call
item.description: The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

item.title: River Murray, Coorong, Lake Alexandrina listed as critically endangered
item.description: Environmental protections along a huge stretch of the River Murray will be boosted, following a decision to officially list the area as "critically endangered", the federal government says.

item.title: Stolen Generation artwork discovered in trunk of regional WA museum
item.description: An artwork drawn by a child of the Stolen Generations more than 70 years ago is discovered after decades in the trunk of a regional museum.

item.title: Workers on Melbourne farm supplying Woolworths, Coles chase unpaid wages worth $260,000
item.description: According to court documents, at least 20 workers are owed money for the work they did in late 2023 on Corrigan's Farm in south-east Melbourne, which experts say is part of a bigger problem that sees tens of millions in missing cash disappear into the black economy.

item.title: Australian Open 2026: Record crowds for 'Opening Week' leave some fans frustrated
item.description: The Australian Open has smashed attendance records in what is being marketed as "Opening Week", featuring fan events and qualifying matches, but the main draw does not start until Sunday.

item.title: Families displaced by Victorian bushfires face uncertain future in tight rental market
item.description: Four weeks after unpacking their last box, a Harcourt family fled fire with only their passports and clothes — and now face a difficult search for a new rental.

item.title: Jordan Smith on winning One Point Slam
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Australian Open 2026: Who is Jordan Smith? The 1 Point Slam winner who beat Jannik Sinner
item.description: Jordan Smith comes from a tennis-mad family in Sydney and is now a millionaire thanks to a couple of days' work at the Australian Open.

item.title: From dumped shark heads to rising fury — how WA's demersal fishing ban turned ugly
item.description: Western Australia's ban on demersal fishing has left fishers frustrated. Will the government be able to soften the blow for an angry industry?

item.title: Australian Open 2026 draw puts Alex de Minaur against former Wimbledon finalist in tough first round
item.description: In the first round, the world number six will face off against Matteo Berrettini, a former Australian Open semifinalist — a place De Minaur has never progressed to himself.

item.title: Antonio Arena scores for Roma, raising questions over whether he will play for the Socceroos or Italy
item.description: In Italy, he has earned the nickname Il Baby Bomber because of his size, strength and impact on the game. But where do his international allegiances lie?

item.title: Neo-Nazi figure Joel Davis denied bail over alleged threat to federal MP
item.description: High-ranking neo-Nazi Joel Davis has told a Sydney court the Nationalist Socialist Network "no longer exists" as he was again denied bail for allegedly threatening a federal MP.

item.title: Tom Silvagni, son of AFL star, outlines rape conviction appeal grounds
item.description: Details of the 23-year-old's appeal bid have been released, with Silvagni arguing a judge erred in describing certain evidence as "incriminating conduct" during his rape trial late last year.

item.title: Blooming corpse flower at Adelaide Botanic Garden set to attract thousands
item.description: A corpse flower at the Adelaide Botanic Garden is generating excitement but it is actually among five of the rare plant to bloom in the city this summer.

item.title: WA health infrastructure audit delivers scathing assessment of hospital maintenance
item.description: An audit of WA's health infrastructure finds the state's aging public hospitals are too reliant on reactive maintenance, with no dedicated funding to keep them up to scratch and little data to inform future decisions.

item.title: Why Australia is investing in defence infrastructure at five military sites in the Philippines
item.description: Experts say these agreements are clear signs of how important an ally the Philippines is becoming in the Indo-Pacific region amid jitters of US security guarantees.

item.title: Greens won't support Labor's sweeping hate law reform in current form
item.description: The Greens have thrown up a roadblock for Labor by declaring it will not support the government's sweeping changes to hate and gun laws without amendments as the Coalition also backs away from the reforms.

item.title: Surgeons appear in court over alleged secret payments in Queensland hospitals
item.description: Two surgeons and the co-owner of a medical device company face Brisbane Magistrates court over their alleged involvement in public hospital fraud, allegedly involving secret payments to surgeons.

item.title: Dane Sweeny battles into Australian Open main draw
item.description: A delighted Dane Sweeny will play in the Australian Open main draw for the second time after winning his third and final qualifying match.

item.title: Anxious business owners fear collateral damage from WA's illegal tobacco violence
item.description: Business owners neighbouring suspected illegal tobacco stores are calling for a crackdown amid a spate of violent incidents alleged to be targeting the illicit tobacco trade.

item.title: Behind Grok's mass digital undressing lies an 'unsurprising' cohort of 'men eager to violate women'
item.description: The X AI is not creating sexually explicit images of women on its own, but the software "facilitates their abuse" acting on the requests of men "eager to violate women".

item.title: Thanasi Kokkinakis pulls out of Australian Open singles, hopeful Special Ks can still play doubles
item.description: Thanasi Kokkinakis has pulled out of the Australian Open singles before the draw could be announced after suffering a shoulder injury playing in Adelaide.

item.title: Name change for viral app Are You Dead, designed for young people living alone
item.description: A viral Chinese app named Are You Dead aimed at people living alone has been rebranded to avoid controversy.

item.title: Police investigating fraud claim against director of liquidated caravan manufacturer Zone RV
item.description: The luxury caravan manufacturer will be wound up, with liquidators promising to step up their investigation into allegations against Zone RV director David Biggar.

item.title: Laura Stein appointed as South Australia's new Chief Justice, replacing Chris Kourakis
item.description: Supreme Court Justice Laura Stein has been announced as South Australia's new Chief Justice — the first woman to be appointed to the role.

item.title: United Employment collapse leaves disability workers $6 million short in missing pay, super and entitlements
item.description: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

item.title: International Grammar School teacher Peter Adam in custody over child sexual abuse claims
item.description: A Sydney school teacher accused of plotting the sexual assault of two children he was allegedly "pimping out" to another man is refused bail.

item.title: Bushfire relief payments cause confusion among Victorians in impact zones
item.description: Residents from Victoria's bushfire-affected areas say they are confused over disaster relief payments, with a number of people saying they have been rejected for relief despite experiencing hardship.

item.title: Thursday finance with David Chau
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Wikipedia is 25, but some old fights are still going
item.description: Wikipedia is celebrating 25 years of the online encyclopedia and the enormous impact its had, while looking forward to its future. But some controversies from the past refuse to die.

item.title: Premier Jacinta Allan vows to request formal review into Victoria's bushfire disaster
item.description: Jacinta Allan vows to request a formal review of the state's disastrous bushfire season, following days of questions over issues like Country Fire Authority resourcing and the state's disaster preparedness.

item.title: Ecologist Dr Faith Coleman steps down from government panels after allegations of political interference
item.description: South Australian ecologist Dr Faith Coleman has resigned from two state government algal bloom panels and criticised the state government's approach.

item.title: Space station astronauts splash down after first-ever medical evacuation
item.description: A capsule carrying four International Space Station crew members has splashed down in the Pacific, bringing their mission to an end more than a month early.

item.title: Astronauts return from ISS with sick crew member
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: More than 4.7m social media accounts closed in two days after ban began, data reveals
item.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

item.title: Antidepressants less effective for many living with atypical depression, new study finds
item.description: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for about 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

item.title: Pulp agree to Adelaide Festival show after apology to Randa Abdel-Fattah
item.description: In a social media post, British indie band Pulp says it had previously informed festival organisers of its decision to withdraw but was asked "to delay an announcement while [organisers] sought to resolve this crisis for all sides", and it had now agreed to perform.

item.title: Australia's notorious Bass Strait was once conquered by two men in a 4.5m dinghy
item.description: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

item.title: Heated Rivalry and growing sports romance genre can teach lessons about queer inclusion
item.description: Heated Rivalry has become a massive global hit, but can the steamy ice hockey romance, and other queer love stories, help create more inclusive spaces in the real sporting world?

item.title: What is in the government's new hate speech laws?
item.description: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

item.title: Hundreds of satellite images capture Victoria's destructive bushfires erupting
item.description: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

item.title: Former Whyalla steelworks owner's $18.5 million royalties debt revealed
item.description: The former owner of the Whyalla steelworks, Sanjeev Gupta's OneSteel Manufacturing, owed $18.5 million in royalties when it was forced into administration last year, the ABC can reveal.

item.title: Queensland woman wakes up to find carpet python on top of her
item.description: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her, she was rattled.

item.title: Who could lead Iran if the Islamic Republic falls?
item.description: Names frequently raised include an exiled prince, a former president, and the leader of a leftist movement, but experts say no single figure has the power and legitimacy to take control alone.

item.title: Child slapped in the face among inappropriate educator discipline exposed in Canberra childcare document dump
item.description: Documents detailing five years' worth of childcare breaches in the ACT reveal cases of educators slapping children, forcibly shaking them, throwing them, and possessing child exploitation material.

item.title: Finn Allen smashes maiden BBL century as Perth Scorchers book finals spot
item.description: Finn Allen saves his best ever BBL innings for when it matters most as the Perth Scorchers out-duel the Melbourne Renegades.

item.title: 'Apocalyptic Christian cult' Shincheonji using 'special force teams' to spread across the country
item.description: Documents leaked to the ABC reveal an "apocalyptic Christian cult" is targeting Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong and Darwin.

item.title: Hamnet's historical figures are brought to life, only to be robbed of depth
item.description: Chloé Zhao's retelling of the life of William Shakespeare is on the fast track to the Academy Awards, but at times feels like Oscar-bait.

item.title: The NT's last private obstetrician walks away as maternity services face collapse
item.description: A growing number of women in the Northern Territory are travelling interstate to give birth — or leaving the territory altogether — following the sudden closure of the only private hospital maternity ward. Now, the NT's last private obstetrician is closing her practice.

item.title: Wall Street rallies on Taiwan chips, Jim Chalmers backs Michele Bullock over US Fed chair — as it happened
item.description: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has come out in support of Michele Bullock after the Reserve Bank governor signed a joint statement in solidarity with Mr Powell, who is facing criminal prosecution driven by US President Donald Trump.

item.description: Struggling to find answers about what happened in the week leading up to her death in hospital, Sue Smith's loved ones say they want hospitals to put more resources into investigating these types of incidents.

item.description: City of Canning Mayor Patrick Hall is awarded a quarter of a million dollars in a lengthy defamation fight with one of his own constituents over a series of social media posts.

item.title: Christmas Island welcomes 'twice-in-a-decade' return of millions of baby red crabs
item.description: Wildlife officials on Christmas Island, the remote territory 2,600 kilometres north-west of Perth, are welcoming the final chapter of its famous red crab migration — the return to shore of millions of baby crabs.

item.description: Two wineries in the Strathbogie Ranges have lost a combined 150 hectares of vines, 3,000 sheep and three homes in the Victorian fires.

item.description: Once seen as barren landscapes, feedlots across Australia have been reshaping their image. With industry encouraging its operators to install shade, uptake has been widespread.

item.description: A key weather radar in WA's north is expected to be offline for at least three months, leaving farmers and pastoralists facing financial losses and safety risks.

item.description: They call themselves the "Sea Shells Teabaggers" — and with marathon swimmer Shelley Taylor-Smith at the helm, this ocean swim group has built something much stronger than good technique.

item.title: Twenty-four parkruns in 24 hours no sweat for Albany runner Ben Castlehow
item.description: An Albany man runs roughly three marathons in laps of a hilly parkrun to raise funds for a charity that helped him through a tough time.

item.description: The freshwater crayfish is becoming more popular in restaurants across Australia, but the industry faces challenges boosting production as more farmers retire.

item.description: A family holidaying at Wye River on the Great Ocean Road have been lucky to escape flash flooding less than a week after catastrophic fires drove them from their central Victorian home.

item.title: Belle Brockhoff, former snowboard cross world champ, forced to retire weeks before Winter Olympics
item.description: Former snowboard cross world champion Belle Brockhoff announces her retirement just weeks out from the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics, due to a series of significant long-term injuries.

item.title: Japan begins test mining seabed for rare earth minerals to reduce reliance on China
item.description: Tokyo hopes the plan to mine as much as 16 million tonnes of rare earths will help reduce its reliance on China, but will it work?

item.title: Kimberly Birrell and Taylah Preston lose semifinals in Adelaide and Hobart
item.description: It was a tough ask from the outset for Kimberly Birrell, coming up against the teen sensation Victoria Mboko who has been in excellent form of late.

item.description: The United Nations committee has determined Australia breached its international legal obligations by allegedly exposing an asylum seeker from Iran to torture in immigration detention.

item.title: Top religious leaders call on PM to scrap plan to outlaw promotion of racial hatred
item.description: A broad of coalition of Australia's most influential religious leaders have urged the prime minister to scrap Labor's proposal to outlaw the promotion of racial hatred.

item.title: Social media's impact on Australian teenagers' wellbeing isn't black and white, new study finds
item.description: The findings of a newly released study have challenged one-size-fits-all rules and blanket bans, as the Australian government's social media ban for children under 16 has been in effect for over a month.

item.title: Police say 10 tennis courts' worth of poppies stolen in recent theft
item.description: Investigations are continuing into the theft of a large quantity of poppy capsules from a Tasmanian farm. Police have confirmed the harvested area equates to 10 tennis courts, or 2,500 square metres.

item.description: The mother of a woman who died of "mixed drug toxicity" is pushing for South Australia to implement penalties for those who do not call emergency services in a medical emergency.

item.description: The family of the two men killed when a wall crushed them at the racecourse are disappointed there will be no inquiry into the events of the "terrible day".

item.title: Jim Chalmers defends 'professional' Fed boss Jerome Powell in face of Trump attacks
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers defends US central bank boss Jerome Powell as professional and diligent after the Trump administration launched a criminal investigation into the Federal Reserve chair.

item.description: When it comes to extreme rainfall, it's hard for climate scientists to say what's natural and what's caused by climate change, but they do know the most extreme events are dropping more rain, more often. This is why.

item.description: Former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol is sentenced to five years in jail over crimes relating to his failed attempt at imposing martial law in the country.

item.description: A 47-year-old woman, her son-in-law and her father are granted bail after the AFP charges them, claiming they are allegedly involved in supplying illicit tobacco and vapes.

item.title: From Xinjiang to Tehran: Iran's unrest is shaping China's view of power and world order
item.description: Xi Jinping's ambition is to occupy a central position in a reshaped international system, not to lead a permanent grouping of sanctioned or crisis-prone states.

item.title: Iran, Israel and the US play rapidly shifting roles in the Middle East
item.description: Israel joining with other countries in the Middle East to press Donald Trump not to launch a military strike against a weakened Iran is something that would have seemed incomprehensible even a couple of years ago.

item.title: Today in History, January 17: When Lance Armstrong finally admitted to Oprah he doped his way to seven Tour de France titles
item.description: Lance Armstrong had successfully doped for years. But when the evidence backed him into a corner, he took control of the narrative and confessed live on Oprah's couch, martyring himself to cycling's EPO era.

item.title: Weekend soaking set for NSW and Top End, while Western Australia eyes next cyclone
item.description: January is the middle of Australia's severe weather season and a multitude of hazards are emerging across the country this weekend.

item.title: Natimuk fire offers a glimpse into a new kind of bushfire fuelled by our changing climate
item.description: The anatomy of the Natimuk fire offers a glimpse into a new and faster kind of bushfire — and the growing vulnerability of communities as climate change fuels dangerous conditions.

item.title: British passport changes disrupt plans for reunions, sick relative visits and business trips
item.description: From February 25, dual citizens of the UK and Ireland will be required to enter the UK using a valid British or Irish passport, a change causing major headaches for dual citizens with imminent travel plans.

item.title: Allegations against author Craig Silvey should spark conversations with children
item.description: A prominent parenting expert says serious allegations made against one of Australia’s most renowned authors should spark difficult but important conversations in households across the country.

item.description: The Crown star Khalid Abdalla is in Australia to perform his play Nowhere at Sydney Festival, exploring his experience on the frontline of the Arab Spring in Egypt.

item.title: Olympic climber Campbell Harrison happy to carry weight of being an LGBTQI+ role model
item.description: Campbell Harrison was homophobically trolled in the lead-up to the Paris Olympics. It strengthened his conviction about the importance of visible queer role models in sport.

item.description: Emergency services have defended warning times as locals recover from the record-breaking rains and worst floods in the area since the 1980s.

item.description: As protests shake Iran, massive crowds rising up against the hard-line mullahs and their supporters have been bolstered by the country's younger generations.

item.description: Nicholas Taylor told a court last year that he was abused as a student at a Hobart Catholic school in the 1970s and 1980s. One of his alleged abusers was former Test cricket umpire Stephen Randell.

item.title: Final bow for Tamworth Country Music Festival coordinator Barry Harley
item.description: After 54 years coordinating the Tamworth Country Music Festival, Barry Harley explains it wasn't the drawling tunes that hooked him — but the "family" he made along the way.

item.title: Steve Smith and David Warner trade centuries as Babar Azam fumes in Sixers win
item.description: Steve Smith smashes 32 runs from a single over after denying Babar Azam the strike, leaving the star Pakistan recruit less than impressed.

item.title: The SA premier faced one of his most bruising weeks yet. Will it matter come election time?
item.description: The dramatic cancellation of Adelaide Writers' Week spiralled the news cycle out of Premier Peter Malinauskas's control. But will the saga actually mean anything come the March state election?

item.title: Sarah Blizzard's stunning sportsmanship helps Dutch bobsledders achieve Winter Olympics dream
item.description: With hopes of reaching the Winter Olympics fading due to a dodgy bobsleigh, the Dutch team was running out of answers until Australian Sarah Blizzard rode to the rescue and helped the Netherlands' sliders achieve their dreams.

item.title: Unauthorised ski race planned for Lake Bonney despite national suspension
item.description: A water ski racing group has planned an alleged unsanctioned racing event in South Australia, which the state's Department for Infrastructure and Transport says it has not approved. It comes as the peak body for the sport has nationally suspended racing due to safety concerns.

item.title: Brisbane residents swap apartments for boats as the cost of housing continues to rise
item.description: Living at Brisbane’s Kangaroo Point overlooking the river would typically come with a hefty price tag, but some residents have found an alternative.

item.title: Nelson Asofa-Solomona announces plans to 'clean up the whole NRL division' after successful boxing debut
item.description: Nelson Asofa-Solomona calls out his former rugby league competitors after making a successful transition to the fight game by knocking out Jeremy Latimore.

item.title: Sydney Aboriginal inmate's connection to country stays strong through art
item.description: With each paint stroke and dot placement, art gives John the opportunity to express his culture, with some of his fellow Aboriginal inmates joining him in creating artworks while incarcerated.

item.title: Tasty one-tray lemon garlic chicken with green beans and potatoes - ABC News
item.description: This bright and flavourful chicken tray bake take just 15 minutes to prep and bakes in one tray.

item.title: These 'seats of knowledge' offer daily connection and a few laughs.
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Age-old 'seat of knowledge' tradition alive and well in North Queensland
item.description: Every day in these North Queensland towns, familiar faces gather to have a yarn in public spaces — just as people have done for centuries.

item.title: Sea trials begin in Hobart for Incat's Hull 096 China Zorilla, the world's largest electric ferry
item.description: It is a world first — and years in the making — and when the massive electric ferry moved out into open water in Hobart for testing, there was a "big sigh of relief".

item.title: Outback NSW lake home to hundreds of turtles set to run dry in 130-year first
item.description: Imperial Lakes Nature Park may soon dry out for the first time in over a century, creating an environmental crisis for the region and the hundreds of native animals that call the lakes home.

item.title: Darwin midwife banned from working unsupervised handed $1.1 million NT government contract
item.description: Darwin midwife Claire Marks, who has been placed under a number of conditions by Australia's medical regulator, will continue to run the Northern Territory government's new private practice midwifery service, it's been confirmed.

item.title: Developers propose demolition of Mount Gambier's flour mill walls for new commercial precinct
item.description: As the wrecking ball looms, a community battle is brewing over whether historic flour mill walls need to fall to make way for development.

item.title: Matteo Berrettini fighting illness ahead of Australian Open clash against Alex de Minaur
item.description: Alex de Minaur's first-round opponent, Matteo Berrettini, faces a race against time to be fit for the start of the Australian Open.

item.title: Linguists and First Nations community work together to 'awaken' Bunurong language
item.description: After more than a century of silence, the Bunurong language is being brought back to life by elders, linguists and community.

item.title: Taking paracetamol during pregnancy not linked to autism or ADHD in children, Lancet study finds
item.description: Just months after US President Donald Trump warned women about taking paracetamol during pregnancy, a new study finds there is no evidence linking the painkiller to autism in children.

item.title: Albany's heritage-listed skate park 'The Snake Run' celebrates its 50th birthday
item.description: Australia is home to one of the world's oldest surviving skate parks, which is as much a product of surfing culture as it is a time capsule of skating history.

item.title: Greek tourist Ioannis Vidiniotis flooded with support after tragic accident at Cottesloe Beach
item.description: A young Greek tourist is flooded with donations and support after a tragic accident at Perth's most iconic beach left him with life-changing injuries.

item.title: Sail Grand Prix fleet hit by early injury blows before race has even begun
item.description: Team Australia has suffered an early injury setback in the lead-up to the opening race of the Sail Grand Prix season, which Fremantle is hosting for the first time this weekend.

item.title: White House names leaders who will oversee Donald Trump's plan for Gaza
item.description: The White House has released the names of leaders who will play a role in overseeing the next steps in Gaza, under the so-called "Board of Peace".

item.title: Fishers and authorities in WA's Gascoyne fear overfishing after demersal ban
item.description: Fishing stocks have rebounded in WA's Gascoyne with authorities hoping it will model recovery efforts statewide. But that success could be undone by fishers fleeing restrictions.

item.title: Jakara Anthony becomes most successful Australian World Cup skier with 26th moguls title
item.description: Jakara Anthony has claimed her 26th moguls title to become Australia's most successful World Cup skier in an imposing sign ahead of next month's Olympics.

item.title: Geraldton's Horizon Ball sculpture draws large crowds as international visitor numbers rise
item.description: Geraldton's Horizon Ball sculpture is drawing huge crowds of tourists after the spot gained international attention on social media.

item.title: US Justice Department opens criminal investigation into Minnesota officials
item.description: Minnesota Governor Tim Walz says the federal justice system is being weaponised to intimidate Donald Trump's perceived political enemies.

item.title: Frustrations as more livelihoods and landscapes lost to Victorian bushfires
item.description: Several Victorian fires have been left out of mainstream media coverage, and one missed out on the Victorian government's initial support list, which has led to disappointment.

item.title: Labor separates gun control laws from hate speech reforms after bill turned down by Coalition and Greens
item.description: The Albanese government will separate laws tightening gun control from its proposed hate speech reforms after the omnibus bill failed to secure the support of the Coalition and the Greens.

item.title: Myanmar denies deadly Rohingya campaign amounts to genocide
item.description: The South-East Asian country's armed forces launched an offensive in 2017 that forced over 700,000 ethnic Rohingya from their homes into neighbouring Bangladesh.

item.title: Chinese debate Iran crisis as official and public views diverge
item.description: As protests rage in Iran, Chinese netizens are openly debating freedom, repression and global power politics, even as Beijing keeps its criticism focused on Washington.

item.title: Michael Zerafa has been accused of quitting against Nikita Tszyu. There is no more heinous crime in boxing
item.description: To be called a quitter is the lowest insult in boxing. But whether Michael Zerafa was guilty of this or not, he has successfully ostracised himself from the sport's fraternity for the second time in his career.

item.title: Machado's peace prize gift shows she's betting on a future with Trump
item.description: Lacking leverage with the United States, María Machado makes a calculated move to gift her Nobel Peace Prize to President Donald Trump. It underscores her willingness to think long-term.

item.title: Woman dies after tree falls on her car south of Wollongong as winds and rain lash NSW coast
item.description: Emergency services were called to the Illawarra Highway near Clover Hill Road just before 4pm after a tree branch fell onto a passing vehicle on a busy road.

item.title: Debutants Sweden tied for lead, Australia fourth after day one of SailGP Fremantle
item.description: SailGP debutant Sweden is locked in a three-way tie for the lead after the first day of racing in Fremantle, with the Australian boat Flying Roos well placed in fourth spot heading into Sunday's races.

item.title: Why the chase for the grand slam record is not a burden for Novak Djokovic ahead of Australian Open
item.description: After two years stuck one shy of the all-time grand slam titles record, Novak Djokovic believes the Australian Open is as good a place as any to make his greatest piece of history.

item.title: Lawyers, rights groups and civil libertarians call on NSW Police Commissioner to not extend protest restrictions
item.description: Lawyers, human rights advocates and civil libertarians are urging the NSW Police Commissioner not to extend a ban on authorised public assemblies as January 26 approaches.

item.title: 'I'm back!' Australian cricket great Damien Martyn shares heartfelt update on remarkable recovery
item.description: Australian cricket great Damien Martyn has paid tribute to the support he has received during his remarkable recovery from meningitis, while revealing he was given a "50:50 chance" of surviving the illness.

item.title: Indonesian flight goes missing with 11 on board
item.description: Search and rescue crews have been deployed to the mountainous area of Maros Regency to look for the plane.

item.title: Thousands protest in Denmark, chanting 'Greenland is not for sale' in response to Trump's threats
item.description: Chanting "Greenland is not for sale" and carrying banners saying "Hands off Greenland", thousands of people have marched in Denmark, responding to US President Donald Trump's ambitions to acquire the Artic island.

item.title: Iran's leader Khamenei blames Trump for inciting deadly protests
item.description: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has labelled Donald Trump a criminal, blaming him for the deaths of thousands of demonstrators and security forces.

item.title: Meet the Australian volunteers changing lives on a hospital ship in Africa
item.description: On the largest civilian hospital ship in the world, Australian volunteers provide life-changing healthcare that is transforming lives.

item.title: How charging board or rent to adult children can help them and you
item.description: Experts on the benefit of charging board and expenses if you’re sharing a home with young adults, and how to calculate it.

item.title: Russian President Vladimir Putin wants to 'make a different world' and Iran is vital to his plan
item.description: Tehran is the epicentre of the nightly protests shaking Iran's regime, but the reverberations are being felt loud and clear in Moscow, too.

item.title: Liberal Party election autopsy delayed after Peter Dutton suggests report defames him and his staff
item.description: The report, co-authored by Liberal grandees Pru Goward and Nick Minchin, has now been sent to a legal team to ensure it is watertight while the party decides what step to take next.

item.title: Donald Trump announces tariffs for eight countries as Greenland stand-off continues
item.description: Donald Trump announces the escalating tariffs for Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Finland as a row over Greenland continues.

item.title: BHP gaining ground as CBA loses its shine in market power struggle
item.description: The year is barely underway but already there's a power struggle between our biggest corporations as they fight it out for line honours.

item.title: Hard Quiz: Refreshed after a break and ready to flex your trivia muscle?
item.description: Wow, you really don't quit. Let's see how poorly you perform this week.

item.title: Two women reinvent and rediscover themselves in outback Queensland
item.description: Sam wanted to "rediscover who she was in my 20s", so she left her family and life behind to chase an outback adventure.

item.title: Australian woman documents her stint in Chinese weight loss 'prison'
item.description: Camps offering intensive weight loss programs are on the rise in China as the country faces skyrocketing obesity rates.

item.title: Iranian protesters are calling on Trump to intervene — but the shadow of 1953 still haunts the US
item.description: Protesters are urging US President Donald Trump to help dismantle Iran's theocracy. If he answers the call, it won't be the first time the US government has toppled an Iranian government.

item.title: Sam Kerr scores twice for Chelsea in Women's FA Cup, declares her best form is not far away
item.description: Sam Kerr declares she is approaching her best form after scoring twice for Chelsea in a Women's FA Cup victory over Crystal Palace.

item.title: Supreme Court case continues despite more than 200 interpreter errors
item.description: A Victorian Supreme Court trial is forging ahead with amended transcripts after an interpreter made more than 200 translation errors during a key witness' evidence.

item.title: Facebook group transforms into charity led mainly by local women
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Grandmother's support group becomes a lifeline for Lithgow
item.description: It started as a Facebook page and now it is a vital charity. Here is how this group run by grandmothers is fighting loneliness in the NSW Blue Mountains.

item.title: Fire approaches a resident's house in Terip Terip
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: As bushfires swept across Victoria, Terip Terip's volunteer brigade fought to survive
item.description: The volunteer brigade from Terip Terip went through "hell" and back, narrowly escaping death while fighting to save their own community and those nearby.

item.title: Bree Walker claims monobob silver as Australians build up to Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics
item.description: Sledder Bree Walker finishes second in the overall monobob standings after winning silver in Altenberg, Germany, on another day of success for Aussie Winter Olympic hopes.

item.title: Mount Lofty Ranges koala population boom risks starvation, study finds
item.description: South Australia's Mount Lofty Ranges is experiencing a koala population boom that would likely lead to starvation and deaths, researchers say.

item.title: Forgotten tracks from the 2005 Hottest 100 you need to hear again
item.description: We've dug out some standout tracks from the Hottest 100 of 2005 that you need to hear again. Relive the mid-2000s music that defined an era.

item.title: Bourke artist Jenny Greentree's career sprouted during millennium drought
item.description: Jenny and Steve Greentree's young family faced losing everything in the millennium drought. Twenty years on, their thriving art gallery has helped to put Bourke on the map.

item.title: Women's Tour Down Under first stage marred by crashes to Australian Liv Jayco AlUla team
item.description: The Australian Liv AlUla Jayco team is out to rescue its women's Tour Down Under campaign after a painful start in Saturday's opening stage.

item.title: Documents reveal dangerous staffing failures inside Canberra's childcare centres
item.description: Staffing and supervision gaps at Canberra childcare centres have resulted in children sustaining broken bones and dislocated jaws, regulator files have revealed, prompting the ACT government to promise change.

item.title: Australian breakdancers aim to redefine Olympic image ahead of Brisbane 2032 decision
item.description: Inside the prestigious Brisbane City Hall in the countdown to the 2032 Olympics, thumping music shakes the walls where almost 200 breakdancers from across 33 countries gather to compete.

item.title: B-Girl Royal, also known as Guo Pu is a rising Chinese break dancer
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Why Abbey Barrett's mum wants more federal government help funding brain cancer research
item.description: Abbey was "joy on two legs" and now she's gone, another lost to brain cancer. Somehow her family must carry on as the fight for more funding to bring this horror disease to an end continues.

item.title: Tasmanian teen Zeke Woolcock says building bike jumps taught him leadership, and researchers agree
item.description: Authorities destroying bike jumps built illegally by kids is not a new thing, but research indicates that those authorities should instead seek to work with young people, like Zeke Woolcock, on building trails.

item.title: The central Queensland town of Agnes Water and its surfing culture
item.description: Former professional surfers and board makers have chosen this small coastal paradise as their home, but with smaller waves, what makes it so special?
